title: Data Analysis
text:
This document details our data cleaning and preprocessing workflow for the Lightcast job postings dataset. We document all transformations to ensure reproducibility and transparency in our analysis.



Dataset: Lightcast Job Postings
Time Period: [Your date range]
Raw Data Location: data/raw/
Processed Data Location: data/processed/

title: Data Analysis
text:
Dataset: Lightcast Job Postings
Time Period: [Your date range]
Raw Data Location: data/raw/
Processed Data Location: data/processed/

title: Data Analysis
text:
2.1 Dropping Unnecessary Columns
We remove redundant NAICS/SOC codes and tracking data to simplify our dataset. Keeping only the latest NAICS_2022_6 and SOC_2021_4 ensures that our analysis reflects current industry and occupational classifications.

2.1.1 Columns Removed:

ID, URL, ACTIVE_URLS: Tracking metadata not needed for analysis
DUPLICATES: Redundant with our deduplication process
Old NAICS codes (NAICS2-6): Superseded by NAICS_2022_6
Old SOC codes (SOC_2, SOC_3, SOC_5): Superseded by SOC_2021_4

title: Data Analysis
section: 2.2 We remove redundant NAICS/SOC codes and tracking data to simplify our dataset. Keeping only the latest NAICS_2022_6 and SOC_2021_4 ensures that our analysis reflects current industry and occupational classifications.
text:
2.2 We remove redundant NAICS/SOC codes and tracking data to simplify our dataset. Keeping only the latest NAICS_2022_6 and SOC_2021_4 ensures that our analysis reflects current industry and occupational classifications.


Code
import pandas as pd
import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import seaborn as sns
import plotly.express as px
import missingno as msno

# Load raw data
df = pd.read_csv("data/raw/lightcast_job_postings.csv")

# Display original shape
print(f"Original dataset: {df.shape[0]} rows, {df.shape[1]} columns")

# Drop unnecessary columns
columns_to_drop = [
    "ID", "URL", "ACTIVE_URLS", "DUPLICATES", "LAST_UPDATED_TIMESTAMP",
    "NAICS2", "NAICS3", "NAICS4", "NAICS5", "NAICS6",
    "SOC_2", "SOC_3", "SOC_5"
]

df.drop(columns=columns_to_drop, inplace=True, errors='ignore')

print(f"After dropping columns: {df.shape[0]} rows, {df.shape[1]} columns")
print(df.head)

After dropping columns: 72498 rows, 118 columns

title: Data Analysis
text:
2.4 Removing Duplicate Job Postings
To ensure each job is counted only once, we remove duplicates based on job title, company, location, and posting date.


Code
df = df.drop_duplicates(subset=["TITLE", "COMPANY", "LOCATION", "POSTED"], keep="first")

print(df.head)

title: Data Analysis
text:
2.5 Job Postings by Industry
Understanding industry demand helps job seekers prioritize skill development.


Code
fig = px.bar(df["NAICS_2022_6"].value_counts(), title="Job Postings by Industry")
fig.show()

title: Data Analysis
text:
2.6 Salary Distribution by Industry


Code
fig = px.box(df, x="NAICS_2022_6", y="SALARY", title="Salary Distribution by Industry")
fig.show()

title: Data Analysis
text:
2.7 Remote vs. On-Site Jobs


Code
fig = px.pie(df, names="NAICS_2022_6", title="Remote vs. On-Site Jobs")
fig.show()

title: Data Analysis
text:
2.3 Handle Missing Values
We use different strategies for missing values:

Numerical fields (e.g., Salary) are filled with the median.
Categorical fields (e.g., Industry) are replaced with “Unknown”.
Columns with >50% missing values are dropped.



Code
# Visualize missing data
msno.heatmap(df)
plt.title("Missing Values Heatmap")
plt.show()
